Module 4.1

Making Tables

Prework

  • get a us census api key
  • install tidycensus, install.packages("tidycensus")

tidy census basic usage

acs table info

library(tidycensus)
census_api_key = my_api_key # enter your census api key here in quotes

View and use the search function in the viewer. Search for “household income.”

v21 <- load_variables(2021, "acs5", cache = TRUE)

#View(v21)
library(stringr)
library(dplyr)

quintiles <- get_acs(geography = "state", 
                      variables = c(q1 = "B19081_001",
                                    q2 = "B19081_002",
                                    q3 = "B19081_003",
                                    q4 = "B19081_004",
                                    q5 = "B19081_005",
                                    top5 = "B19081_006"),
                      year = 2021,
                      output = "wide") |>
                      select(
                        !ends_with("m"), # eliminate margin of error
                        -GEOID) |> # eliminate geo id
                      rename(name = NAME) |>
                      rename_with(~str_remove(., 'E'))
    

glimpse(quintiles)
Rows: 52
Columns: 7
$ name <chr> "Alabama", "Alaska", "Arizona", "Arkansas", "California", "Colora…

$ top5 <dbl> 336788, 394694, 395620, 344470, 555007, 466181, 602707, 420859, 6…

Explore the data

Use slice to explore data and select some cases.

Where do the wealthiest people live?

library(kableExtra)

top_10 <- quintiles |>
  slice_max(top5, n = 10)

kable(top_10)
name q1 q2 q3 q4 q5 top5
District of Columbia 12971 51060 94478 157803 375792 670768
Connecticut 17417 48870 84042 133488 319533 602707

Illinois 15102 42688 72900 114531 258373 466713

What states have the lowest incomes?

library(kableExtra)

bottom_10 <- quintiles |>
  slice_min(q1, n = 10)

kable(bottom_10)
name q1 q2 q3 q4 q5 top5
Puerto Rico 2906 12144 22163 38397 99043 187234
Mississippi 10096 27963 49418 80125 175581 308523
Louisiana 10371 29781 53925 89536 201514 357026
New Mexico 11058 31274 54295 86905 188282 323568

South Carolina 12680 34881 58665 92118 207367 374427
District of Columbia 12971 51060 94478 157803 375792 670768

Maybe instead of the following, I could select a stratified random sample of states within each tier.

library(dplyr)

# lowest 
state_min = quintiles |> 
  slice_min(q1) |>
  select(name) |>
  pull() # convert from tibble to vector

# highest
state_max = quintiles |> 
  slice_max(top5) |>
  select(name) |>
  pull()

# randomly select five more

five_more = quintiles |>
  slice_sample(n = 5) |>
  select(name) |>
  pull()

states <- c(state_min, state_max, five_more)

states
[1] "Puerto Rico"          "District of Columbia" "Washington"          
[4] "Idaho"                "North Dakota"         "Nebraska"            
[7] "Kansas"              
states_data <- quintiles |>
  filter(name %in% states) |> 
  arrange(desc(top5))

kable(states_data)
name q1 q2 q3 q4 q5 top5
District of Columbia 12971 51060 94478 157803 375792 670768
Washington 19367 50803 82817 127003 277165 487950
Kansas 15817 40065 64780 99380 215122 383038
North Dakota 15507 41406 68558 104602 217143 380261
Nebraska 16506 41590 66977 100910 213091 378679
Idaho 16450 40433 63643 95316 203042 360622
Puerto Rico 2906 12144 22163 38397 99043 187234

gt tables

gt gt reference

library(gt)

gt(states_data) |> 
  tab_header(
    title = "Mean Household Income of Quintiles, 2021",
    subtitle = "Seven Representative U.S. States"
  ) |> 
  cols_label(
    name = "",
    q1 = "lowest",
    q2 = "second",
    q3 = "third",
    q4 = "fourth",
    q5 = "fifth",
    top5 = "top 5%"
  ) |> 
  fmt_currency(
    columns = c(q1, q2, q3, q4, q5, top5),
    currency = "USD", 
    use_subunits = FALSE
  ) |>
  # note that you can use markdown (md) to format the source note for html documents
  tab_source_note(source_note = md("**Source**: US Census Bureau, American Community Survey"))
Mean Household Income of Quintiles, 2021
Seven Representative U.S. States
lowest second third fourth fifth top 5%
District of Columbia $12,971 $51,060 $94,478 $157,803 $375,792 $670,768
Washington $19,367 $50,803 $82,817 $127,003 $277,165 $487,950
Kansas $15,817 $40,065 $64,780 $99,380 $215,122 $383,038
North Dakota $15,507 $41,406 $68,558 $104,602 $217,143 $380,261
Nebraska $16,506 $41,590 $66,977 $100,910 $213,091 $378,679
Idaho $16,450 $40,433 $63,643 $95,316 $203,042 $360,622
Puerto Rico $2,906 $12,144 $22,163 $38,397 $99,043 $187,234
Source: US Census Bureau, American Community Survey
